1.author: angel_boo
1.body:
I think you're an idiot who doesn't take care of your pet. Ask your vet, they will say to trim the nails. Read the link I added above. 

Take care of your pet!

1.author: Lost_property_
1.body:
In the UK folk often allow their cat outside, where they trim their claws by scratching on surfaces (stuff like trees). They also have many scratching posts inside, so even indoor cats are able to trim their claws down.

I’ve never heard of someone clipping a cats claws. Don’t think it’s a thing in the UK. If you adopt a cat a scratching post is one of the items you must have in your home to support claw health.

Edit: the link you shared states to keep something on hand for then they bleed. Clipping a cats claws is avoided in the UK for this reason; it’s seen as painful and cruel.

1.author: angel_boo
1.body: If you have someone who knows what they are doing clip the claws, the cat doesn't get hurt. I have 3 different sets of scratching posts in my house and still need to clip their claws. I have never caused my cats to bleed when clipping their nails.

1.author: Lost_property_
1.body:
The link you shared states to have something at hand for the bleeding which tells me this is a common occurrence.

Not saying one way is correct. Just pointing out the rationale for why claws aren’t clipped in the UK.

We also don’t allow declawing, tail and ear docking in dogs etc so there are cultural and legal differences.

3.author: brnaftreadng
3.body: Fun fact (if you didn’t already know). Caiques are one of the only parrots that you can have a bonded pair and they will still bond with you! They are one of my favorite breeds☺️

3.author: Derekbair
3.body:
That’s one of the main reasons we got one over other parrots. I wasn’t going to be happy getting a parrot and then it choosing someone else over me! These guys are very gregarious and are even friendly with strangers. 

Gizmo still wants us even tho he has his new temporary buddy although I think a girlfriend is in his near future after all the fun he is having with another caique. 

Same can’t be said about him and our budgies- he wants to assassinate them!

3.author: brnaftreadng
3.body: Oh nooooo! They can be so headstrong and stubborn when they set their sights on something. Hopefully with a new buddy his mission for budgie annihilation will be forgotten 😂

3.author: Derekbair
3.body: Doesn’t seem like it. Now they can attack from both sides! Lol I’m not sure if they just lunge at them to scare them away or if they would really bite them but it doesn’t seem friendly and I don’t want to risk it. Which is unfortunate cause my budgie Lucio REALLY wants to play with them.

5.author: MonkeyTacoBreath
5.body:
Depends on who is delivering. Amazon has a contract with USPS, and of course they can deliver to mailboxes. But if shipped UPS or FedEx, usually an Amazon marketplace seller, not going thru Amazon fulfillment centers, they cannot deliver in post boxes in the US.

OP stated they live in Australia, so unlikely they have the same law.

5.author: razzledazzlegirl
5.body:
Knowing the posties in Australia (or at least where I live), either in the postbox next to it (regardless of the fact it’s not mine), or on the ground.

Thankfully this was my parcel and my postbox is empty again.

14.author: PO_Boxer
14.body: And in 1973 HMOs became a thing. By the 80s prices were getting out of hand. By the 90s HMOs began to dictate terms to providers and patients ensuring profitability. through the decade, the number of HMOs grew and so did the public’s participation.  The very organizations that were envisioned to create competition and lower prices have not met the mark largely because of shareholder needs. Profit does not solve this, it just creates more need for even more profit. The growth model  shouldn’t be anywhere near the healthcare industry.  There should be no shareholders benefitting from healthcare, it’s fucking madness.

14.author: kcabyats
14.body: Ok but the prices literally started in 1967 and that was it from them on. Then insurance companies can take advantage and know that they will get paid no matter what because now the government is involved with a neverending supply of tax money. I'm not saying insurance companies and corporations aren't to blame as well. What I'm saying is that the initial problem that allows these people to take advantage is the government being involved. Drug companies can price a drug at anything they want because the government will pay it instead of letting it compete in the free market.

14.author: PO_Boxer
14.body: You seem to be mostly anti-government. So in this case the beginning was the important part to you in this narrative.  Ok.  I’m not seeing your solution in any practical terms.  My creeds are bribery/lobbying out of government  and profit out of healthcare.  Simple, tangible.

14.author: kcabyats
14.body: I'm anti government involvement. Not anti government. The government exists to ensure that our constitutional rights are protected. Once the government becomes involved then the corruption begins and an industry suffers. The only solution is a hard one. Get government out of healthcare. No more subsidies, paying for anything, or programs. It will hurt some for a bit but be better in the long run. I agree we could go backwards step by step but companies are clever and corruption goes too deep. They will just find ways around. I say go all right away.

17.author: XarrenJhuud
17.body: Ah, so you're one of those "pray it away" types. I was in the 99th percentile in grades 3 and 4. That means only 1 percent of students performed better than I did. Intelligence and social skills are not indicative of adhd. And btw, the phrase "alphabet kids" is a slur against the lgbt community and has no connection to medical disorders. Though I  get the feeling you knew that

17.author: coach111111
17.body:
You North American? Seems everyone over there is diagnosed with something. You guys love your diagnoses. Let me ask you. Did your doctors diagnose you over the internet? 

Go straight to rehab, don’t pass go, don’t collect $200. You’ll thank me in five years.

17.author: XarrenJhuud
17.body: Refusing to accept that neurodivergent disorders exist isn't going to make them disappear. I feel sorry for your daughter, whether or not she has a disorder. You seem like a horrible person.

17.author: coach111111
17.body: No no don’t get me wrong. It’s clear from this comment section they exist.

17.author: XarrenJhuud
17.body: Just not in your family, right? Absolutely abhorrent behavior

17.author: coach111111
17.body:
No. I’ve got family with disorders. Prader-Willi and accompanying  severe scoliosis . I just wouldn’t ever think to insinuate based on a comment online the fact that a child prefers playing over bathroom breaks that they’ve got a disorder. That’s simply asinine. 

You have no idea what such a comment could set in motion if you plant that idea in the wrong person’s head. I’ve seen impressionable people firsthand be affected harder than you would imagine by asinine comments on social media.  

Find something better to do than to project these things on random people based on next to zero information.

Edit; try doing this irl next time you see a young kid rushing to the bathroom with their parent, and see how quickly someone slaps you silly.

17.author: XarrenJhuud
17.body: I'm not projecting, I have no idea if your child has adhd or not. That's why I suggested you get her tested. Then you went off about how there's nothing wrong with her. Unless you have had her tested, or are a doctor qualified to make a diagnosis, you don't know either.

17.author: coach111111
17.body:
I have no idea who you are or next to anything about you. Let me suggest you might have a condition though. Yea that’s sane. 

Why don’t you just go to a kindergarten during drop off and espouse this advice to all parents.I’m sure most of them haven’t had their kids tested either. Maybe you should team up with someone with another disorder and double up on the good advice. Print some flyers too.  Sound like a good idea? Try that and come back and tell me what you learnt.

17.author: XarrenJhuud
17.body: If I'm showing signs of a condition you're aware of and I'm not, then advising me to get checked is great advice. Worst thing that happens is I wasted a bit of time at a doctor's office. I don't get what about this is so hard for you to understand. No one is saying your daughter is defective, or that having a medical condition is a bad thing. I'm just advising you to look out for your daughter's best interests. I'm done replying to you now, goodbye.

24.author: Jacobysmadre
24.body:
I’m very at home in the water as I grew up and still live in Southern California. But for some reason I think because I just couldn’t put my feet down I started to panic. 

I would love to get prescription goggles and take SCUBA lessons so I could really enjoy bit next time and go out over the retaining wall to the open part of the bay… :) 

Thanks for all the suggestions, it can never hurt to practice!

24.author: Speakdoggo
24.body: Yea, I understand. I have issues with that as well. I used to swim apx 1/4 - 1/2 mile offshore in Hawaii but parallel to  one beach the dolphins were behind me.  Could hear their clicks and sounds, but it wasn’t the usual “ happy “ clicks. It was the stressful ones. The water was so murky , couldn’t see 20-30 feet ahead. I finally gave in to my fear and headed to shore. Some ppl there said did you see the false killer whales following you? A pod had followed me for the short swim , maybe half mile each direction. ( I didn’t see them) They are known to be one of the only dolphins to be aggressive to humans. Yikes right?

24.author: Speakdoggo
24.body: Oh ! My bad . I assumed u weren’t . Well the dead man’s float is a good thing to know anyways … if u ever get the time . Cheers!

24.author: Jacobysmadre
24.body: Nooooo! Don’t be sorry because it’s been years and anyone reading can be helped by this!!! Cheers!!

24.author: Speakdoggo
24.body: Yea, that’s true. Hope somebody picks up on it and goes to learn it. I remember teaching it to my husband 30 years ago when he said he’d always been uncomfortable in water. It only took him maybe 15 min to really get it and then it was just such bliss …watching him maneuver around the pool with just little brush strokes of his hands, hardly any movement at all. He was like a slow turtle … relaxed and having his first peaceful water experience
